thread.title: Neighbouring 100-year-old houses in Coorparoo face demolition
thread.title_full: Neighbouring 100-year-old houses in Coorparoo face demolition

author: Jim Malo
title: Neighbouring 100-year-old houses in Coorparoo face demolition
text:
The best off-the-plan buys in Brisbane Developers are expected to knock down two near-100-year-old family homes for sale in Coorparoo after their owners grew too old to take care of the properties. 
Ray White Holland Park agent Braco Dracic said the houses were built in the 1920s and had not left the Szogi family since. 
“It is a regretful sale but that’s just mother nature doing it’s own job,” Mr Dracic said. “People get older, too tired for renovations and the like.” 
48 and 52 Pembroke Road, Coorparoo, two old Queenslanders up for sale. Photo: Supplied 
Nos. 48 and 52 Pembroke Road would need major work if they were to be lived in but still held the character from when they were first built, Mr Dracic said. 
“The houses are in original condition,” he said. “If you walk in the houses, everything is really original.” 
“I think they’re some of the oldest houses in the area.” 
Looking at 48 Pembroke Road from the street. Photo: Google StreetView 
Though the Szogis are sad to say goodbye to family homes, Mr Dracic said, there was an opportunity to attract a developer to the 1810-square metre double block. 
Demographer Mark McCrindle said development in Coorparoo would continue gradually, with townhouses and dual story apartment blocks making up the bulk of new construction. 
“What’s ideal is when the development is a more sustainable development,” he said.”“If you have areas that move from detached homes for multilevel developments it can create resentment and a negative images with residents.” 
The boundaries of the 1810 square metre property outlined. Photo: Supplied 
Smaller builds would become more common in inner-city suburbs as developers become more community conscious, Mr McCrindle said. 
“Those are more well regarded in Brisbane rather than the larger full scale developments, which, in this area, would be a bit over the top,” he said. 
Special approval from the Brisbane City Council would be needed to demolish the houses. Mr Dracic said one potential buyer had already said they would apply to demolish the properties, rather than move them. 
The Szogis were not open to selling the blocks separately yet, but Mr Dracic said there was some interest in saving at least one of the properties from demolition. 
“We have had a bit of interest from a lady in the street who offered a reasonable price for one of the houses for restoration.”
